ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of optimization, microeconomic intuition.
Advanced calculus using Lagrange, same topics as in intro micro except using calculus to answer more advanced questions, and game theory models.
I learned a lot about microeconomics and the mathematical skills needed to understand the concepts better.
I learned about economics from a micro point of view.
I developed my math skills and economics knowledge. Also gained more insight into how markets/firms work and co-operate with each other.
Learning more about multi variable optimization by using the Lagrangian. Definitely math heavy

I was able to understand economics more in terms of optimization. I think I have been able to rekindle my calculus skills and have been able to apply them to real-life problems with various types of units. Along with this I have taken some more interest in economics and might continue it more in the future.

Lagrangian, General Equilibrium, Monopolies, Oligopolies, Game Theory, Collusion, Risk, Expected Utility

More generally: the basics of how firms interact in our economy, and how we can start to picture how firms work together (or conspire against each other). Introduction to social security, prisoner's dilemma, subsidies, and taxes
Mainly Lagrangian approaches to economics.
I learned how to apply the principles of calculus to concepts that were learned previously in the introductory course.

I have acquired knowledge related to the firm's behaviors in the market set by taking this course. There are several models introduced throughout the five weeks of classes. In particular, Professor Hawkins offered insights into the firms' action from perfect competition to the monopoly market. I believe those instructions will be greatly beneficial for me to continue pursuing the academic path related to economics.
Intermediate micro!

Expenditure minimization and the dual problem.  Income and substitution effects. Competitive equilibrium in exchange economies.The firms problem.  Profit maximization, cost minimization, and supply curves. Competitive equilibria with production. Market power overview.  Monopoly.  Deadweight losses and price discrimination. Nash equilibria. Oligopoly models.  Mergers and cartels. Uncertainty and risk:  Expected Utility and insurance. Adverse selection and moral hazard.
I got a strong understanding of the math behind microeconomics and optimization -- dealing with many of the edge cases. We covered a broad swath of material at an accelerated pace.
I leaned the higher level concepts behind the basic economic relationships I leaned about in intro micro.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's extremely intense and difficult to follow at times, but the material is useful

We did lots of problems in class which were super helpful to reinforce information that was lectured on. I especially appreciated this because not many economics professors take the time to do this and I felt that I was more prepared to tackle the problem sets. The TA's were also very helpful in section - we went over the problem sets every week.

The material was taught well but given the condensed time frame it was difficult to get enough practice on the concepts. Each topic really only had one single practice question associated with it, so any variation of the problem on an exam was much more difficult and slightly unexpected.

Strengths: The class was very structured/organized and well taught. 
Weaknesses: I wish there was more interaction between everyone in the class, but it was hard given the virtual setting.
it was a good course, nothing to really make better.

The course was good, just a bit rushed which made it difficult to grasp some of the complicated math topics. In a normal term, this course is likely fine but the summer-format made it sometimes difficult to understand the math. Other than that the course was good, it was interesting enough that the 3hr lectures did not feel too terrible, and Professor Hawkins keeps things interesting by bringing in a lot of real-world examples.

The strengths of this course were the way that the concepts were taught to us and there was a good amount of problems to practice on in preparation for exams. I also think this that this course was very fair in the exams, if you were on your stuff throughout the whole course. Very little weaknesses, not much I would change, pretty solid course.

In my opinion, the course was very well taught, especially for a five-week course. The expectations of the course were fair and clearly lined out from day one, and the structure of the course was very reasonable - 3 problem sets, a midterm, and a final examination. Examinations and problem sets were great in that they were both challenging but also forced you to think and explore the material. Jonathan is a great person and a good teacher who really tried to answer every question in class and humanize the material (and complex algebra), and the course provided enough TF support during the summer to help students really understand the material. Virtual classes are also the best thing since sliced bread.

The syllabus and class discussions were well-organized but the course materials sometimes were not. It may be helpful in the future to post things a little earlier, especially the problem set and midterm/final examination solutions. Also, announcements when materials are uploaded (and concrete dates as to when they will be) would be extremely helpful. I completely understand, however, that this might not have been possible due to the abridged schedule and the novelty of the course. 

I'm also uncertain about the structure of the course in solving complex algebra problems during class time on the board. I do feel like a lot of the muddling through algebra during class time could have been shortened with pre-written latex or algebra, leaving time for discussion on more real-world applications or problems? (For example, just having all of the latex solutions written out). It was also confusing at times to follow the algebra, especially when looking back at the derivations as there were steps that were "skipped" on the board. But to be honest, I'm not 100% sure on this - the algebra was helpful at times when we worked through each problem, and the course material is already tough enough that this might not be needed? Either way, not sure.

Regardless, this course served as a great introduction to microeconomics (far better and more fair than the intro sequence) and would highly recommend. This is the first time the course was offered in the summer, so I expect the course will only improve as it is offered in later sequences.

Strengths: Professor and TF accessibility; Structures to facilitate learning

Weaknesses: Sometimes vague understanding of what we needed to know for the tests

A strength of this course was that the teaching fellows and instructor were very helpful in trying to provide explanations for concepts that may not have been clear to me. A weakness was that the tests were extremely focused on doing math properly and did not really test your understanding of concepts as much as I wanted them to.

The course is very rigorous overall, and compressing it into a five-week curriculum is challenging for many students who take this course. There is a tremendous amount of knowledge to cover, and I would say illustrating and adding more examples into the curriculum can help me, at least, to sink in the knowledge. We had three problem sets and two exams throughout the course. I would suggest including some quizzes, and another type of assessment other than the psets and exams would be helpful to improve the course.
Great classs
The course was very well run for an online course. However, the TFs could've have slightly longer office hours because they often felt rushed.

The course covered a good swath of material and made me feel comfortable with the content. I thought it sometimes got a little bit in the weeds with the math (esp in the psets), but I suppose this added to the rigor of it. For covering game theory at such an accelerated pace, I thought it was covered very well (as someone who took a Game Theory class before).

As a product of Yale summer session, the content moved very quickly and due to the relatively complex nature of some of the topics, it was difficult to keep up with class some of the weeks. Breaking the content down into shorter but more frequent lectures would have improved this.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a prereq for the major
If you are interested in economics, yes.
It's a requirement of many majors so it has to be taken. The topics are interesting but don't know how useful they would be in real life unless you wanted to continue studying econ afterward.
Yes. It was fast-paced, but it was easy to follow.
if microeconomics is your thing, this is a great course. microeconomics is not my thing, i did not enjoy the course.
If you are interested in the topic, I would recommend taking it. It is well-taught and interesting material that with a bit of work is feasible to grasp quite well.

Yes, I would. Especially if you can take it during the summer, I would go for it. The sequence during the school year is miserable, competitive, has a tough curve, and does not offer time for individualized attention. This course was fun (well, as fun as algebra can get). Just be prepared to work, but if you work hard you can really get something out of this class.
Only if required. Although the material is interesting, it's a heavy course.
I would recommend this course to another student if they have an interest in math and seeing how some calculus concepts can apply to the real world, as that is what this course was really about.
Only if required
I would if the student has a strong background in both economics and applied math.
Yes!
Yes, if they're interested in economics. Jonathan is one of the best economics professors I've had at Yale.

Yes. For a summer course, we covered an impressive amount of material, while the (largely graded on completion) problem sets and section (which covered many of the problem set questions) structure easily prepared you for exams.
I would recommend the course to another econ student but not to any other since the topic and application is relatively niche.
